channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: Japan and US Seek to Strengthen Ties as Kishida Visits
item.description: Hovering over a state visit to Washington is the possibility of a swing in American foreign policy if Donald Trump returns to the White House.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: President Biden with Prime Minister Fumio Kishida of Japan at the NATO headquarters in Brussels in 2022.

item.title: A C.I.A. Black Site Remains a Touchy Subject for Lithuania
item.description: Despite rulings in European courts saying the Baltic country was home to a secret prison, the issue has been shrouded in official secrecy in a nation closely allied with the United States.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Andrej Vasilenko for The New York Times
item.media:description: The former C.I.A. site, code-named Site Violet, in Antaviliai, Lithuania.

item.title: Gazans Are Turning to This Wild Plant for Survival
item.description: Palestinians have long gathered and cooked khobeza, a spinach-like wild plant that sprouts after rains. Now, it has become a lifeline.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Bilal Shbair
item.media:description: Selling khobeza leaves in Rafah, in southern Gaza, in February. The plant is making up an outsize portion of many Gazans’ diets by providing a lower-cost way to blunt hunger.

item.title: South Korea’s Election Is About ‘Gladiator Politics’
item.description: This week’s parliamentary elections are widely seen as a referendum on both President Yoon Suk Yeol and his archrival, Lee Jae-myung, the opposition leader.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: Lee Jae-myung of the Democratic Party and Yoon Suk Yeol of the People Power Party during the presidential election campaign in Seoul in 2022.

item.title: Middle East Crisis: Gaza Cease-Fire Talks to Resume in Cairo
item.description: Negotiators were expected to discuss potential terms of a temporary cease-fire and the release of Israeli hostages. More protests were planned in Israel.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: People lighting candles during a protest against Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s government, and calling for the release of hostages, in Tel Aviv on Saturday.

item.title: Homecoming
item.description: A single photo captures a moment of setback for families who had tried for a better life.
item.media:credit: Elise Blanchard for The New York Times

item.title: Peter Pellegrini Wins Slovakia’s Presidential Election
item.description: The victory for Peter Pellegrini, an ally of Slovakia’s populist prime minister, strengthens Central Europe’s ties to Moscow.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:description: Peter Pellegrini casting his ballot in Bratislava in the first round of Slovakia’s presidential election in March.

item.title: 30 Years After Rwandan Genocide, Ruler Holds Tight Grip
item.description: Thirty years after a devastating genocide, Rwanda has made impressive gains. But ethnic divisions persist under an iron-fisted president who has ruled for just as long.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: President Paul Kagame of Rwanda in 2021. The architect of the country’s stunning transformation, he achieved it with harsh methods that would normally attract international condemnation.

item.title: Pardoned for Serving in Ukraine, They Return to Russia to Kill Again
item.description: Recruiting convicts for its army has given Russia a manpower advantage. But it is backfiring in tragic ways when former inmates are pardoned and return home to commit new crimes.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar and Milana Mazaeva
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Russian military recruitment billboard saying, “Heroes are not born, they are made,” last year in Ulan-Ude, Russia. Veterans who survive the front line return to Russia as heroes with an elevated status in society.

item.title: Another Israeli Hostage’s Body Recovered, the Death Angering His Family
item.description: Like the families of other hostages, they are outraged that the Israeli government has yet to reach a deal to halt the fighting and bring home loved ones held in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman and Anna Betts
item.media:description: A March protest in Tel Aviv demanding the release of the Oct. 7 hostages. At center, a woman holds a poster of Elad Katzir, whose body was recovered Friday by the Israeli military.

item.title: Mexico Breaks Diplomatic Ties With Ecuador After Jorge Glas Arrest
item.description: Jorge Glas, a former vice president, had taken refuge at the Mexican Embassy in Ecuador’s capital. Mexico’s president called his arrest a violation of international law.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon, Isabella Kwai and Julie Turkewitz
item.media:description: Ecuadorean police officers entered the Mexican Embassy in Quito on Friday night to arrest Ecuador’s former vice president.

item.title: Why Time Is Running Out Across the Maldives’ Lovely Little Islands
item.description: Global tourism brought a modern economy to the country’s thousand islands. For many Maldivians, the teeming capital beckons.
item.dc:creator: Alex Travelli, Maahil Mohamed and Elke Scholiers
item.media:description: Teenagers gathering to watch the sun set in Nolhivaranfaru, a remote island in the Maldives.

item.title: More Myanmar Political Prisoners Are Dying in Military Prisons
item.description: The country’s military rulers have signaled a new wave of detentions and, rights groups say, conditions for existing prisoners have deteriorated.
item.dc:creator: Caleb Quinley
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: A bus carrying prisoners exiting Insein prison in Yangon, Myanmar, in January. The junta has said it will release thousands of prisoners, but rights groups warn that any freedom is likely to be temporary.

item.title: Who Is Jorge Glas, an Ecuadorean Politician Arrested at Mexico’s Embassy?
item.description: A former vice president of Ecuador, Jorge Glas had been convicted of bribery in two separate cases. He had fled to the Mexican Embassy in Quito after facing more embezzlement charges.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: Ecuador’s former vice president, Jorge Glas, after his release from prison in Quito, Ecuador, in 2022.

item.title: The Israeli hostage whose body was returned Saturday had spoken of feeling unsafe.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Maya Palty, left, rallied for her relative Elad Katzir in January. Mr. Katzir had deep roots in Nir Oz, the kibbutz in southern Israel where he was born and from which he was abducted on Oct. 7.

item.title: New England Journal of Medicine Ignored Nazi Atrocities, Historians Find
item.description: The New England Journal of Medicine published an article condemning its own record during World War II.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Nazaryan
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Fox Photos Ltd./Sydney Morning Herald, via Alamy
item.media:description: Nazi doctors and scientists on trial at Nuremberg in 1947 for human experiments, murders and other atrocities during the Holocaust.

item.title: Israel Says It Recovered Body of Elad Katzir, an Oct. 7 Hostage
item.description: Elad Katzir lived near the border with the Gaza Strip. His sister said Israel’s government should have done more to get him back alive.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.media:description: Supporters held posters of Elad Katzir during a protest in Tel Aviv in February.

item.title: Russian Missiles Hit Kharkiv, Killing at Least 6
item.description: The latest assault on the eastern city killed at least seven people, local authorities said. As Kyiv waits on American aid, Moscow has stepped up bombardments, including using modified “glide bombs.”
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:description: A bomb crater at the scene of an overnight attack in Kharkiv, eastern Ukraine, on Saturday.

item.title: Eclipse Mania
item.description: There’s still reason to get excited, even if you’re not convinced by the hype.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Iran vows revenge at a funeral for commanders killed in an Israeli airstrike.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi, Eric Schmitt and Ronen Bergman
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Trucks carrying the coffins of seven Iranian commanders killed in an Israeli airstrike in Syria passed by mourners in Tehran on Friday.

item.title: Trudeau Gives Preview of Canada’s Federal Budget, Breaking Tradition
item.description: Breaking with Canadian tradition, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau has been crisscrossing the country announcing measures from the April 16 budget in advance.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Jeff Mcintosh/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau at a housing announcement in Calgary on Friday.

item.title: Gaza War Turns Spotlight on Long Pipeline of U.S. Weapons to Israel
item.description: President Biden sends arms to Israel under an Obama-era $38 billion aid agreement that runs until 2026. Israel’s purchases include the types of bombs dropped in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley and Edward Wong
item.media:description: An Israeli Blackhawk, an American-made helicopter, during a drill in northern Israel in February.

item.title: U.S. Seeks ‘Results’ After Israel Promises More Gaza Aid Routes
item.description: World leaders welcomed the shift by an Israel facing increasing pressure, but they stressed that the measure of success would be whether enough trucks get in to ease the humanitarian crisis.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd, Raja Abdulrahim and Michael Levenson
item.media:description: A makeshift tent camp for displaced people in Rafah in the southern Gaza Strip on Thursday.

item.title: Senior Tory MP William Wragg Admits Sharing Colleagues’ Private Data on Grindr
item.description: William Wragg said he had been scared that a man he met on the Grindr dating app had “compromising things” on him, and apologized for causing “hurt.”
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: U.K. Parliament/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: An undated photo released by the British Parliament of William Wragg, a conservative lawmaker, who admitted that he had given the phone numbers of fellow members of Parliament to someone he met on Grindr.

item.title: Iran Vows Revenge at Funeral for Commanders Killed in Israeli Airstrike
item.description: The Israeli airstrike this week in Damascus that killed seven Iranian commanders was an unusually harsh blow, and officials say Iran is determined to respond, raising fears of a war.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi, Eric Schmitt and Ronen Bergman
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: A funeral procession Tehran on Friday for seven Iranian military commanders killed by an Israeli airstrike in Syria on Monday.

item.title: Is Bird Flu Coming to People Next? Are We Ready?
item.description: Unlike the coronavirus, the H5N1 virus has been studied for years. Vaccines and treatments are available should they ever become necessary.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:credit: Rachel Bujalski for The New York Times
item.media:description: Avian influenza, which is often fatal in birds, surprised officials when it was found in dairy cows in multiple states.

item.title: Gazans Describe Search For Food and Wonder If It Will Get Worse
item.description: The charity food group World Central Kitchen suspended its relief efforts after seven of its workers were killed in Israeli airstrikes.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: Suhail al-Asaad, a body builder, at home in 2022.

item.title: IDF Says Hostage Likely Killed by Helicopter Fire on Oct. 7
item.description: An inquiry found that a combat helicopter had “fired at a vehicle that had terrorists in it” but also, “in retrospect,” hostages.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:description: During a protest last year in Prague, people held posters, some showing Efrat Katz. She was among those seen being kidnapped on Oct. 7.

item.title: Why Real Madrid Is Soccer’s Model Club
item.description: The club is strutting into a future different from the one envisioned by its president, Florentino Pérez. But its prospects are as bright as ever.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith
item.media:description: Real Madrid players celebrating a win over Barcelona in October.

item.title: McDonald’s to Buy Back 225 Israeli Restaurants After Boycotts
item.description: The move highlighted deepening political rifts for multinational corporations in the region and followed boycotts after the chain’s Israeli franchise owner donated meals to soldiers.
item.dc:creator: Liz Alderman
item.media:description: McDonald’s said that the chain’s 5,000 workers in Israel would keep their jobs.

item.title: Author Who Defected From North Korea Wins Defamation Lawsuit
item.description: Jang Jin-sung​, known for his memoir “Dear Leader,” was accused of rape by a fellow North Korean defector. He sued her and a South Korean broadcaster and won.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: Jang Jin-sung in London in 2012.

item.title: After 6 months of war, some Israelis wonder if Netanyahu is dragging it out.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Some in Israel accuse Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of keeping the war going to prevent a collapse of his fragile coalition government.

item.title: Tensions Run High at Al Aqsa Mosque on the Last Friday of Ramadan
item.description: The Israeli police said they arrested eight people at the compound in Jerusalem, where thousands of Muslim worshippers had come for dawn prayers amid heavy security.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd

item.title: Israeli Military Says Series of Failures Led to World Central Kitchen Attack
item.description: “It’s a serious event that we’re responsible for, and it shouldn’t have happened,” Rear Adm. Daniel Hagari said of the strike that killed seven World Central Kitchen workers.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman and Adam Rasgon
item.media:description: United Nations staff members inspecting a car used by World Central Kitchen workers that was hit by an Israeli airstrike in Gaza this week.

item.title: Blinken Presses Israel Over Its Announcement of New Aid Routes
item.description: Under pressure from President Biden, Israel said it would allow new aid routes into Gaza, but it remains to be seen when they will open or how much they will provide.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:description: The port of Ashdod in Israel on Friday.

item.title: After 6 Months of War, Some Israelis Ask: Is Netanyahu Dragging It Out?
item.description: Despite growing pressure from President Biden, the Israeli prime minister appears in no rush to end the war in Gaza. Some think he has political reasons for extending the stasis.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, center, at a cabinet meeting in December. Some in Israel accuse him of keeping the war going to prevent a collapse of his fragile coalition government.

item.title: Dwindling Ammunition Stocks Pose Grave Threat to Ukraine
item.description: What few munitions remain are often mismatched with battlefield needs as the country’s forces gird for an expected Russian offensive this summer.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers firing a howitzer toward Russian forces in the Donetsk region of Ukraine last month.

item.title: Documentary Filmmaker Explores Japan’s Rigorous Education Rituals
item.description: Her movies try to explain why Japan is the way it is, showing both the upsides and downsides of the country’s commonplace practices. Her latest film focuses on an elementary school.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich
item.media:credit: Andrew Faulk for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ema Ryan Yamazaki, a half-British, half-Japanese filmmaker, chronicles moments that she believes form the essence of the Japanese character, for better or worse.

item.title: There’s an Explosion of Plastic Waste. Big Companies Say ‘We’ve Got This.’
item.description: Big brands like Procter & Gamble and Nestlé say a new generation of plants will help them meet environmental goals, but the technology is struggling to deliver.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:credit: Maddie McGarvey for The New York Times
item.media:description: Recycled polypropylene pellets at a PureCycle Technologies plant in Ironton, Ohio.

item.title: U.N. Rights Body Calls for a Halt to Arms Transfers to Israel
item.description: The resolution adds diplomatic weight to international demands to curb the supply of weapons being used in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Nick Cumming-Bruce
item.media:description: In recent days, the Biden administration authorized delivery of an arms package that included thousands of bombs to Israel, and it is pressing Congress to allow the sale of $18 billion worth of F-15 fighter jets.

item.title: In Australia, a Nation’s Banh Mi Love Affair
item.description: “We’ll make the best of it here. And they can call it a pork roll.”
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Banh mi.

item.title: Friday Briefing
item.description: The Times’s Jerusalem bureau chief on six months of war between Israel and Hamas.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik
item.media:description: Mourning relatives killed during strikes in Rafah.

item.title: Netanyahu Faces Pressure at Home and Abroad, From Foes and Friends
item.description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has the challenge of trying to defeat Hamas while preserving both his government and Israel’s international alliances.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd, Victoria Kim and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel has come under sharper criticism from allies including the United States.

item.title: Israel Agrees to Open Erez Crossing for Gaza Aid After Biden Pressure, U.S. Says
item.description: Israel has come under rising pressure from U.S. officials and humanitarian agencies to allow more aid into Gaza, amid warnings that famine is looming.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd and Erica L. Green
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers at the Erez border crossing in December.

item.title: NATO Wants to Show Support for Ukraine, but Only So Much
item.description: Admitting Kyiv is a nonstarter as long as the war with Russia is raging. But the member nations want to show they are supporting Ukraine “for the long haul.”
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Soldiers of the 32nd Mechanized Brigade in the Kharkiv region of Ukraine on Monday. Ukraine hopes for a formal invitation to join NATO.

item.title: Iran Says 17-Hour Battle With Separatists Leaves 28 Dead in 2 Cities
item.description: Jaish al-Adl, an ethnic Baluch group designated by the United States as a terrorist organization, claimed responsibility for the attacks.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and Leily Nikounazar
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Iranians breaking their fast on Wednesday during Ramadan in Tehran near a giant banner of Gen. Mohammad Reza Zahedi, who was killed on Monday in an Israeli airstrike in Syria.

item.title: Richard Benedick, Negotiator of Landmark Ozone Treaty, Dies at 88
item.description: He played a key role in securing the Montreal Protocol, an international environmental pact to protect the ozone layer by reducing the use of certain chemicals.
item.dc:creator: Trip Gabriel

item.title: Friday Briefing: Six Months of the Israel-Hamas War
item.description: Also, the rise of “carefluencers.”
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Praying during Ramadan at a ruined mosque in Rafah, Gaza.

item.title: Eyeglasses Improve Income as Well as Sight, Study Shows
item.description: A study found that when farsighted workers in Bangladesh were given free reading glasses, they earned 33 percent more than those who had not.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Jacobs
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: According to the W.H.O., the lack of access to corrective eyewear inhibits learning among students, increases the likelihood of traffic accidents and forces middle-age factory workers and farmers to prematurely leave the work force.

item.title: Israeli Military Cancels Leave for Combat Units After Airstrike in Syria
item.description: Though no reason was given for the moves, Israeli newspapers said they came amid fears of an increased threat from Iran after an Israeli strike in Syria.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers in Gaza during a media tour conducted by the Israeli forces on Sunday.

item.title: Kuwaitis Vote With Hope for Change Amid Political Turmoil
item.description: With a new ruler in charge, the oil-rich emirate elected a new Parliament for the fourth time in four years while grappling with political turmoil.
item.dc:creator: Yasmena Almulla and Vivian Nereim
item.media:description: With a portrait of Kuwait’s ruler, Sheikh Mishal Al Ahmed Al Sabah, looming overhead, Kuwaitis voted for Parliament in Al Riqqa district on Thursday.

item.title: Israel to Add Gaza Aid Routes After Biden’s Tense Call With Netanyahu
item.description: The president denounced the killing of seven humanitarian workers in a tense call with Israel’s prime minister. Within hours, Israel agreed to increase aid deliveries.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:description: During a 30-minute call with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, President Biden went further than ever in pressing for change in the military operation.

item.title: Finland School Shooting’s Motive Was Bullying, Police Say
item.description: The police said the motive emerged during interviews with the student, who after the shooting also threatened students heading to another school.
item.dc:creator: Johanna Lemola and Emma Bubola
item.media:credit: Jussi Nukari/Lehtikuva, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A flag at half-staff on the grounds of the school in Vantaa, Finland, on Wednesday.

item.title: Sexual Assault of Migrants in Panama Rises to Level Rarely Seen Outside War
item.description: The New York Times interviewed more than 70 people who said they had been victims of armed robbery. Fourteen were women who said they had suffered sexual violence.
item.dc:creator: Julie Turkewitz and Federico Rios
item.media:credit: Federico Rios for The New York Times

item.title: How an Editor’s Note on Kate Middleton’s Video Fueled Conspiracy Theories
item.description: A routine Getty Images caption beside the Princess of Wales’s cancer announcement has fanned disinformation about her. Researchers say there is no evidence that the video is fake.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: In a prerecorded video released on March 22 by the palace, Catherine, Princess of Wales, announced she had cancer.

item.title: Denmark Closes Shipping Lane Over Risk of Accidental Missile Launch
item.description: The military said the missile malfunctioned during a test aboard a warship, and there was a possibility it could fly a short distance, but no risk of the warhead exploding.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses and Maya Tekeli
item.media:credit: Lars Laursen/Ritzau Scanpix, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The Great Belt Bridge in Denmark on July 2022.

item.title: Venice to Charge Tourists an Entry Fee to Discourage Overcrowding
item.description: Starting this month, tourists intending to visit the city on busy dates will be required to register on a website, and those coming for a single day will have to pay an entry fee.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Rialto Bridge in central Venice in 2022.

item.title: A Tantalizing ‘Hint’ That Astronomers Got Dark Energy All Wrong
item.description: Scientists may have discovered a major flaw in their understanding of that mysterious cosmic force. That could be good news for the fate of the universe.
item.dc:creator: Dennis Overbye

item.title: Why Taiwan Was So Prepared for a Powerful Earthquake
item.description: Decades of learning from disasters, tightening building codes and increasing public awareness may have helped its people better weather strong quakes.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley, Meaghan Tobin, Siyi Zhao and Lam Yik Fei
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times

item.title: World Central Kitchen Demands an Independent Investigation Into Israeli Strike
item.description: The Israeli military, which has accepted responsibility for the strike, has started looking into the killings of seven aid workers. But the disaster relief organization said that was not enough.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: United Nations staff members inspecting one of the destroyed vehicles used by World Central Kitchen.
